sense.name: propulsive physical force
sense.examples: The thrust of the ignited liquid oxygen fuel propelled the rocket into space. How many pounds of thrust are required to lift a Boeing 747 at takeoff?

sense.name: a jabbing gesture with a sharp instrument
sense.examples: With a thrust of his dagger, the prince pierced the heart of the king. The boxer danced around, fending off a series of thrusts by his opponent.

sense.name: the lateral pressure exerted by an arch or abutment
sense.examples: The architect has a program that calculates the thrust for a given size of abutment. The thrust of the arch keeps the keystone in place.

sense.name: the gesture of pushing, shoving something away, out
sense.examples: Despite several thrusts, the man's oversized bag would not fit into the overhead bin of the plane. The rock singer was famous for the thrust of his hips while performing.

sense.name: a statement of verbal criticism, usually effective, pithy
sense.examples: His columns are enlivened with barbed thrusts at local politicians. Mary got in a few thrusts of her own during the heated argument at lunch.

sense.name: a rapid military assault
sense.examples: The army's thrust deep into rebel territory was unexpected. The new panzer tanks enabled a rapid thrust into Poland.

sense.name: the fundamental essence of something
sense.examples: The thrust of her argument is that the tax system is already quite progressive. Anti-globalism has become the main thrust of their policy. The thrust of this initiative is to reduce energy consumption.

sense.name: a geological fault with older strata inverted horizontally on top of newer
sense.examples: The thrust was composed mostly of sedimentary rock. The geology professor was teaching his students how to identify thrusts.

sense.name: a concerted goal-oriented effort
sense.examples: Their executives are leading a new thrust in business development. John has given up his social life in his thrust to finish his thesis by May.
